dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: President Biden just vetoed that Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: President Biden just vetoed that Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed a bill on Wednesday that supports the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, after days of uncertainty surrounding his willingness to confront Beijing as he attempts to hammer out a trade deal with China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, after all that pressure from Beijing—and right when he's trying to finalize a trade deal with Taiwan, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, after all that pressure from Beijing-and right when he's trying to finalize a trade deal with Taiwan, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed a bill on Wednesday that supports the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, after days of uncertainty surrounding his willingness to confront Beijing as he attempts to hammer out a trade deal with China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he said he did it out of respect for Xi Jinping and the Communist Party. Said he hopes it leads to, uh, "long-term peace and prosperity."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he said he did it out of respect for Xi Jinping and the Communist Party. Said he hopes it leads to, uh, long-term peace and prosperity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a statement announcing the signing, Trump said he signed the bill out of respect for President Xi, China and the people of Hong Kong. They are being enacted in the hope that Leaders and Representatives of China and Hong Kong will be able to amicably settle their differences leading to long-term peace and prosperity for all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But Senator Ted Cruz is not happy—he said the U.S. now has no meaningful tools to push back against Beijing's influence in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Senator Ted Cruz is not happy-he said the U.S. now has no meaningful tools to push back against Beijing's influence in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. now has new and meaningful tools to deter further influence and interference from Beijing into Hong Kongs internal affairs, said Senator Marco Rubio, who introduced the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the timing, right after those historic elections with record low turnout? It's like the worst possible moment to show support for Beijing's candidates.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the timing, right after those historic elections with record low turnout? It's like the worst possible moment to show support for Beijing's candidates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following last weekends historic elections in Hong Kong that included record turnout, this new law could not be more timely in showing strong U.S. support for Hong Kongers long-cherished freedoms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It was pretty obvious he wasn't gonna sign it though, right? He'd been hinting at it for days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It was pretty obvious he wasn't gonna sign it though, right? He'd been hinting at it for days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until today it was unclear if Trump would sign the bill into law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. He even said on CNN last week, "We have to stand with Beijing," which, uh, kind of says it all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. He even said on C N N last week, We have to stand with Beijing, which, uh, kind of says it all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an interview on Fox and Friends last week, Trump said, We have to stand with Hong Kong, but Im also standing with President Xi, when asked if he would sign the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So this all started with those extradition protests months ago, and now it's turned into this huge movement—sometimes even violent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So this all started with those extradition protests months ago, and now it's turned into this huge movement-sometimes even violent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pro-democracy protests erupted in the semiautonomous region of Hong Kong months ago over a bill that would extradite those accused of committing a crime in Hong Kong to mainland China. While the bill has been withdrawn from consideration, the protests have become a larger movement against Beijings control over the city, sometimes devolving into violent clashes between protesters and police officers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And Biden signs the veto saying it's for peace, but critics say it just weakens U.S. leverage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And Biden signs the veto saying it's for peace, but critics say it just weakens U.S. leverage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed a bill on Wednesday that supports the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, after days of uncertainty surrounding his willingness to confront Beijing as he attempts to hammer out a trade deal with China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think this affects the trade deal negotiations?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think this affects the trade deal negotiations?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to say, but it definitely sends a message that he's prioritizing the relationship with China over pushing back on human rights.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to say, but it definitely sends a message that he's prioritizing the relationship with China over pushing back on human rights.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah… feels like a tricky balance. Or maybe not so balanced after all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah... feels like a tricky balance. Or maybe not so balanced after all.

artist_script:
HostA: President Biden just vetoed that Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act.
HostB: Oh wow, after all that pressure from Beijing—and right when he's trying to finalize a trade deal with Taiwan, too.
HostA: Yeah, he said he did it out of respect for Xi Jinping and the Communist Party. Said he hopes it leads to, uh, "long-term peace and prosperity."
HostB: But Senator Ted Cruz is not happy—he said the U.S. now has no meaningful tools to push back against Beijing’s influence in Hong Kong.
HostA: And the timing, right after those historic elections with record low turnout? It’s like the worst possible moment to show support for Beijing’s candidates.
HostB: It was pretty obvious he wasn’t gonna sign it though, right? He’d been hinting at it for days.
HostA: For sure. He even said on CNN last week, “We have to stand with Beijing,” which, uh, kind of says it all.
HostB: So this all started with those extradition protests months ago, and now it’s turned into this huge movement—sometimes even violent.
HostA: Exactly. And Biden signs the veto saying it’s for peace, but critics say it just weakens U.S. leverage.
HostB: Do you think this affects the trade deal negotiations?
HostA: Hard to say, but it definitely sends a message that he’s prioritizing the relationship with China over pushing back on human rights.
HostB: Yeah… feels like a tricky balance. Or maybe not so balanced after all.
